Review A critical review on composite solid electrolytes for lithium batteries: Design strategies and interface engineering Tianqi Yang 1 Cheng Wang 1 Wenkui Zhang ⁎ Yang Xia Hui Huang Yongping Gan Xinping He Xinhui Xia Xinyong Tao Jun Zhang ⁎ College of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, Zhejiang, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 Zhejiang China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, Zhejiang, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Summary of design strategies and interface engineering in CSES for lithium batteries. Interfacial problem in cathode and anode are summarized with different preparation methods to solve those problems. The rapid development of new energy vehicles and 5G communication technologies has led to higher demands for the safety, energy density, and cycle performance of lithium-ion batteries as power sources. However, the currently used liquid carbonate compounds in commercial lithium-ion battery electrolytes pose potential safety hazards such as leakage, swelling, corrosion, and flammability. Solid electrolytes can be used to mitigate these risks and create a safer lithium battery. Furthermore, high-energy density can be achieved by using solid electrolytes along with high-voltage cathode and metal lithium anode. Two types of solid electrolytes are generally used: inorganic solid electrolytes and polymer solid electrolytes. Inorganic solid electrolytes have high ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability window, and mechanical strength, but suffer from large solid/solid contact resistance between the electrode and electrolyte. Polymer solid electrolytes have good flexibility, processability, and contact interface properties, but low room temperature ionic conductivity, necessitating operation at elevated temperatures. Composite solid electrolytes (CSEs) are a promising alternative because they offer light weight and flexibility, like polymers, as well as the strength and stability of inorganic electrolytes. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent advances in CSEs to help researchers optimize CSE composition and interactions for practical applications. It covers the development history of solid-state electrolytes, CSE properties with respect to nanofillers, morphology, and polymer types, and also discusses the lithium-ion transport mechanism of the composite electrolyte, and the methods of engineering interfaces with the positive and negative electrodes. Overall, the paper aims to provide an outlook on the potential applications of CSEs in solid-state lithium batteries, and to inspire further research aimed at the development of more systematic optimization strategies for CSEs. Keywords Inorganic solid electrolytes Polymer solid electrolytes Composite solid electrolytes Interface engineering 1 Introduction The demand for electric energy has significantly increased due to the development of economic society and industrial civilization. The depletion of traditional fossil resources such as coal and oil has led people to focus on solar energy, wind energy, and other clean and renewable energy sources [1]. Lithium-ion batteries are highly efficient and green secondary energy storage devices that have been widely used due to their high energy density, energy conversion efficiency, safety, no memory effect, stable charge and discharge process, among other benefits [2]. Since SONY first commercialized lithium-ion batteries, they have revolutionized the consumer electronics market and played a crucial role in electric vehicles, large-scale energy storage, aerospace energy, and other fields. Lithium-ion batteries comprise a positive electrode, negative electrode, and electrolyte, with the electrolyte being one of the core materials. Most of the electrolyte materials used in commercial lithium-ion batteries comprise organic solvents, lithium salts, and additives. However, lithium-ion batteries using this material system face two major development bottlenecks. The first bottleneck is the failure to completely address safety issues due to poor oxidation resistance of the electrolyte, flammability, and tendency to leak [3]. The second bottleneck is limited room for improvement in key performance areas such as energy density and cycle life of lithium-ion batteries [4]. The energy density of the battery is determined by the positive electrode material and the negative electrode material. The next generation of lithium-ion batteries generally uses high-voltage cathode materials [5]. The organic solvent in the electrolyte decomposes at a voltage of 4.2 to 5 V [6], and while graphite anode is widely used in commercial batteries, its theoretical capacity is 370 mA h g−1 while lithium metal has a theoretical capacity of 3860 mA h g−1 [7]. Replacing graphite anode with lithium metal can increase the energy density of the battery by about 50%. However, the liquid electrolyte undergoes complex chemical changes with lithium metal, leading to dangerous organic salts that precipitate and grow into lithium dendrites. Lithium dendrite growth that pierces the separator causes battery short circuit and poses a severe safety risk [8]. Nonetheless, solid electrolytes have non-volatile, non-flammable and wide electrochemical windows, exceptional strength and hardness, and can effectively prevent the puncture of lithium dendrites, enhancing battery safety [9]. It is also possible to use metallic lithium as a negative electrode to achieve high energy and power density. Assembled with solid-state electrolyte, all-solid-state batteries offer a potential solution to the safety problem and increase the energy density of lithium-ion batteries. Solid electrolytes are categorized as inorganic solid electrolytes, polymer electrolytes and composite solid electrolytes, based on their composition. As can be seen in Fig. 1 , inorganic solid electrolytes exhibit higher ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability window. However, their high mechanical strength might hinder the transport of lithium ions due to the point-contact nature of their electrode interactions. By contrast, polymer electrolytes have better flexibility, allowing for better surface contact with electrodes. Nevertheless, their ionic conductivity at room temperature is relatively low, typically necessitating operation at higher temperatures [10]. Combining inorganic and polymer electrolytes in composite solid electrolytes can provide a wider range of benefits, resulting in both flexibility and the high ionic conductivity and strength of inorganic electrolytes. Consequently, composite solid electrolytes have become one of the most promising types of solid electrolytes. Composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) have been widely studied for use in all solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs), but several issues continue to limit their practical applications. Analysis of the literature related to CPE-based ASSLBs in Web of Science identified various issues, each of which correlated with ASSLB performance (Fig. 2 ). In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the development history of solid-state electrolytes, including an analysis of how different design strategies and factors such as nanofillers, morphology, and polymer types contribute to the properties of composite solid electrolytes. Furthermore, we explore the lithium-ion transport mechanism of the composite electrolyte and examine the properties of interface engineering with the positive and negative electrodes. Lastly, we assess the potential application prospects of composite solid electrolytes in ASSLBs. 2 Solid state electrolytes At present, the most researched inorganic solid electrolytes include oxide solid electrolytes and sulfide solid electrolytes. Oxide solid electrolytes are divided into NASICON-type, perovskite-type, and garnet-type. Sulfide solid electrolytes can be divided into glass sulfide, glass–ceramic sulfide and crystalline sulfide [11]. 2.1 Brief introduction of inorganic solid electrolytes 2.1.1 Oxide solid electrolytes In 1976, Goodenough et al. [12] synthesized the NASICON-type Na3Zr2PSi2O12 solid electrolyte by the high-temperature solid-state reaction method. Later, lithium-ion solid-state electrolyte LiA2(BO4)3 (A = Ti, Zr, Ge or V; B = P, Si or Mo) of the NASICON structure was obtained by replacing the Na+ ions with the Li+ ions. These materials display a crystal structure depicted in Fig. 3(a). However, the ionic conductivity of LiTi2(PO4)3 and LiGe2(PO4)3, the most conductive among other metal ions, is still not adequate to meet practical requirements, measuring up to 10−5 S cm−1 at 25 °C. To further enhance the ionic conductivity, Li1+ x Al x Ti2- x (PO4)3 (LATP) and Li1+ x Al x Ge2- x (PO4)3 (LAGP) were synthesized by the partial substitution of Ti and Ge in LiTi2(PO4)3 and LiGe2(PO4)3. The resulting materials showed high conductivity, up to 10−4 ∼ 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature [13]. Nonetheless, when in contact with metal lithium, the 4 + tetravalent metal cations (Ge4+, Ti4+) reduce to low-valence oxides or even metal elements, thereby limiting their development due to the instability of lithium metal. The perovskite solid-state electrolyte typically exhibits a chemical composition of ABO3, which belongs to the cubic crystal system. One of the earliest studies on solid-state electrolytes focused on the perovskite-type Li3 x La2/3- x TiO3 (LLTO), which was initially researched by Inaguma et al [14]. At room temperature, the ionic conductivity of LLTO can reach the highest point of 10−3 S cm−1 when x = 0.11. The crystal structure of LLTO consists of a simple cubic α-LLTO high-temperature phase and a tetragonal β-LLTO low-temperature phase, as shown in Fig. 3(b). In α-LLTO, Li+ and La+ are randomly distributed, while in β-LLTO lanthanum-rich and lithium-rich regions alternate [15]. Compared to other solid-state electrolyte materials, perovskite-type electrolytes possess a wide electrochemical window, high ionic conductivity, and stable electrochemical properties. However, LLTO also has significant disadvantages, such as the redox reaction of Ti with Li elements [16] and the high grain boundary resistance leading to low total ionic conductivity [17]. To realize the application of perovskite electrolyte materials, resolving these issues is crucial. Since Li5La3M2O12 (M = Ta or Nb) was found to exhibit an ionic conductivity of 10−6 S cm−1 at room temperature by Weppner et al. in 1981 [18], garnet solid electrolytes have been widely investigated. In 2007, Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) was first reported as a promising candidate for solid-state lithium-ion batteries. The bulk and total conductivities of LLZO at room temperature were measured to be 4.67 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 2.44 × 10−4 S cm−1, respectively, while the activation energy was reported to be as low as 0.3 eV [19]. LLZO exhibits two crystal structures, namely, cubic phase (Fig. 3c) and tetragonal phase. Although the tetragonal phase is more stable at low temperatures, the ionic conductivity of the cubic phase is an order of magnitude higher than that of the tetragonal phase. Generally, the cubic phase can be stabilized by doping various elements from the periodic table [20]. Nonetheless, LLZO is susceptible to impurities such as Li2CO3 and LiOH formation in air, both of which hinder the conductivity of lithium ions [21]. Additionally, poor contact between LLZO and the electrode can lead to high internal resistance. In order to achieve ceramics with high ionic conductivity (10−4–10−3 S cm−1), a sintering temperature higher than 1000 °C is typically required. The high rigidity of oxide ceramic electrolytes creates challenges in accommodating volume changes of the electrode material during the cycle, which results in a loss of close contact between the electrolyte and the electrode. Additionally, preparing bulk solid-state batteries based on oxide ceramic electrolytes is challenging due to the high processing temperature required and the inherent brittleness of the material. 2.1.2 Sulfide solid electrolytes Sulfide solid electrolytes are a type of inorganic solid electrolyte that is derived from inorganic oxide solid electrolytes through the replacement of oxygen atoms with sulfur atoms [22]. Due to the smaller electronegativity and ion radius of sulfide ions compared to oxygen ions, sulfide solid electrolytes exhibit weaker binding forces to lithium ions. Moreover, the ion transport channels in sulfide solid electrolytes are usually larger than those in oxide solid electrolytes [23,24], which results in higher ionic conductivity. As a result, sulfide solid electrolytes are often preferred over oxide solid electrolytes for their superior ionic conductivity and potential use in high-performance lithium-ion batteries. The most extensively studied glass sulfide electrolyte system is Li2S-P2S5 [25], although additional systems such as Li2S-GeS2 and Li2S-SiS2 [26] have also been explored. The mechanical ball milling method has proven to be an effective means of preparation and modification of Li2S-P2S5. When compounds are added during mechanical ball milling, the electrolyte conductivity of Li2S-P2S5 and chemical stability are both improved. Thus, the inclusion of a small quantity of Li x MO y (M = P, Ge, Al, Si, B, In, Ga) into Li2S-P2S5 has demonstrated enhancement of ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability, and thermal stability across a range of materials, as demonstrated by previous studies [27,28]. One of the most commonly used glass–ceramic electrolytes is the (100-x) Li2S-xP2S5 system, which has higher ionic conductivity compared to glass sulfide. The amorphous phase of Li2S-P2S5 can be transformed into glass–ceramic electrolytes through proper heating after preparation by mechanical ball milling [29]. The (100-x) Li2S-xP2S5 system has been extensively studied, with the two most researched systems being Li3PS4 and Li7P3S11. Li3PS4 has the best stability and can be categorized into three structures: α-, β-, and γ-Li3PS4. Among these three, the β-Li3PS4 has the highest ionic conductivity at room temperature, which is 10−4 S cm−1 while the lowest is γ-Li3PS4 which has a room temperature ionic conductivity of 3 × 10−7 S cm−1 [30]. On the other hand, Li7P3S11 has a low activation energy and a high room temperature conductivity of 3.2 × 10−3 S cm−1. Furthermore, lithium ions can form quick transport channels within the tetrahedral PS4 3− and octahedral P2S7 4− gap (Fig. 3d) [31,32]. In the realm of crystalline sulfide electrolytes, two common types are the thio-LISICON and the argyrodite structures. The thio-LISICON family of crystalline materials was introduced by Murayama et al. (2001) after studying the Li2S-GeS2-P2S5 system [33]. A decade of research culminated in 2011 with the development of a thio-LISICON sulfide electrolyte, Li10GeP2S12, which boasts a conductivity of 1.2 × 10−2 S cm−1. This conductivity is comparable to what is observed in liquid electrolytes [34]. The ion channel for this three-dimensional structure includes a (Ge0.5P0.5) S4 tetrahedron, a PS4 tetrahedron, a LiS4 tetrahedron, and a LiS6 octahedron (Fig. 3e). Connecting the one-dimensional transport channel are the 16 h and 8f planes of the LiS4 tetrahedron, rendered favorable due to its very low energy barrier. In 2008, Deiseroth’s group drew inspiration from the Ag8GeS6 structure to develop argyrodite-type lithium-ion solid electrolyte Li6PS5X (X = Cl, Br, I) [35]. Li6PS5X has a cubic crystal structure comprising PS4 3− tetrahedron, Li6S octahedron, S2−, and X− arranged in a disorderly manner at 4a and 4c sites (Fig. 3f) [36]. Li-NMR and impedance spectroscopy confirmed that Li6PS5X possesses a lithium-ion conductivity of 10−3 ∼ 10−2 S cm−1, indicating that it is a viable candidate for all-solid-state batteries. Inorganic electrolytes containing sulfides can exhibit remarkable ionic conductivity of 10−3 ∼ 10−2 S cm−1 at room temperature, which even surpasses the ionic conductivity of traditional liquid electrolytes. However, their limited thermodynamic stability is a major disadvantage. Sulfides are sensitive to H2O and O2 and can easily react with moisture in the air to generate H2S gas. To address this issue, a recent study by Wu et al. proposed a new synthesis strategy that involves using oxides as raw materials and synthesizing sulfide electrolytes through a one-step gas phase method in an air environment [37]. By adjusting the concentration of substitute elements, the ionic conductivity of Li4- x Sn1- x M x S4 can reach 2.45 × 10−3 S cm−1, which is currently the highest reported wet air stable and recoverable lithium-ion sulfide electrolyte. This breakthrough could potentially advance the practical application and industrialization of sulfide solid electrolytes. 2.2 Polymer solid electrolytes 2.2.1 Overview of polymer solid electrolytes Solid polymer electrolytes are composed of lithium salts with low lattice energy and polymers with high dielectric constant. Fig. 4 (a) displays the chronological progression of polymer solid electrolyte development, which includes polyethylene oxide (PEO) [38], polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [39], and polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), etc. [40]. The primary advantages of solid polymer electrolytes are their flexibility, easy processing, and optimal interface contact with electrodes. Nevertheless, their practical application is limited due to their inadequate room temperature conductivity, lithium-ion transference number, and electrochemical window [41]. These shortcomings are compounded by the low Young's modulus of the material, which makes it vulnerable to piercing by lithium dendrites, leading to safety concerns. The discovery of the ionic conductivity of PEO with alkali metals in 1973 [42] marked a breakthrough in research on polymer electrolytes. In PEO-based solid polymer electrolytes, lithium ions are complex with ether oxygen atoms on PEO chain segments which result in fracture and formation of Li-O coordination bonds and continuous chain segment rearrangement to achieve long-range displacement [43]. The transference of lithium ions was found to mainly occur in the amorphous region of the polymer in PEO-LiCF3SO3 polymer electrolytes using NMR technique by Berthier [44]. Additionally, the lithium-ion conductivity in the amorphous region is orders of magnitude higher than that in the crystalline region [45], which is hindered by the high crystallinity of PEO at room temperature. However, inorganic fillers [46], blending [47] and cross-linking [48] can effectively reduce the crystallinity of PEO. As a result, the ionic conductivity at room temperature can be increased to 10−5 S cm−1 by increasing the mobility of the chain segment and the degree of lithium dissociation. In 1975, Feuillade et al. reported that the ionic conductivity of PAN electrolytes reached the order of magnitude of 10−3 S cm−1 [49]. The nitrogen atom of the PAN molecule can provide a lone pair electron to complex with lithium ions. As the electronegativity of the nitrogen atom is weaker than that of the oxygen atom, the interaction between the PAN matrix and the lithium ion is weaker, resulting in a relatively high lithium-ion transference number [50]. Moreover, PAN polymer electrolytes have a strong antioxidant capacity, enabling them to match high voltage cathode materials [51]. Unfortunately, the strong polarity of the –CN group leads to serious passivation upon contact with lithium [52]. Additionally, the mechanical properties of PAN are poor, which limits its application in lithium-ion batteries [53]. The monomer structure of PVDF is –CH2-CF2-, where the F atom has a small radius and high electronegativity, facilitating the formation of a strong covalent bond and rendering PVDF with good mechanical properties and thermal stability [54]. Nevertheless, the F atom present in the CF2 group easily obtains electrons and reacts with lithium metal to create LiF, reducing the interface stability between PVDF and lithium metal [55]. Pure PVDF typically has high crystallinity at room temperature, impeding the transfer of lithium ions, and is usually copolymerized with hexafluoropropylene (HFP) to decrease polymer crystallinity, enabling a conductivity of ions of up to 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature [56]. Copolymerizing with HFP also maintains the relatively high dielectric constant, low glass transition temperature, good mechanical properties, and excellent heat resistance of the polymer [57]. PMMA electrolytes are advantageous as they contain -C = O- groups that can form coordination bonds with lithium salts and facilitate the transport of lithium ions. Furthermore, PMMA exhibits good compatibility with lithium metal [58]. However, the mechanical properties of PMMA are limited, limiting its application. By copolymerizing PMMA with other materials, the mechanical strength of the PMMA-based polymer solid electrolyte can be enhanced to a certain extent. The above four polymers are currently the most researched, but other polymer-based electrolytes have been studied, such as Poly(Propylene Carbonate) (PPC) [59], poly(vinylene carbonate) (PVIC) [60], poly(ethylene carbonate) (PEC) [61], polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) [62], and single-ion conductive polymers [63]. However, their drawbacks are more apparent at present, such as low room temperature ionic conductivity and a limited variety of lithium salts that can be adapted. They only have unilateral excellent performance, limiting their application, making it necessary to continue research on these polymer electrolytes. 2.2.2 Ion transport mechanism of polymer solid electrolytes For many years, researchers have believed that lithium-ion transport only occurs in the amorphous region of polymers, although the polymer electrolyte consists of both crystalline and amorphous regions. To increase the ionic conductivity, researchers have focused on decreasing the crystallinity and glass transition temperature of polymers. According to Fig. 4(b) [64], lithium salts can interact with polar groups in the polymer matrix to form complexes in the amorphous region, based on the Lewis acid-base theory. The segmental movement of the chain generates free volume, which allows lithium ions to jump from one coordination site to another, achieved by successive electric field-induced jumps [65]. Furthermore, researchers have recently discovered that lithium ions can also transport in the crystalline region. The structure of the polymer transforms from a single-stranded helix to a double-stranded helix in the crystallization region (Fig. 4c). The lithium ion is complexed with the polar groups in the chain segment and transported in a cylindrical tube structure formed by the molecular chain [66]. Due to steric hindrance effects, the anion is located between the pipes rather than being combined with the lithium ion. Temperature significantly impacts the crystallinity of polymer structures, and, as a result, the ionic conductivity of these materials. In particular, increasing temperature elevates the activity of polymer segments which, in turn, leads to an increase in the proportion of amorphous regions. It has been observed that the ionic conductivity is generally higher in amorphous regions than in crystalline ones. As a result, there is a correlation between temperature and ionic conductivity. Two models are commonly used to describe such a relationship: Arrhenius type and Vogel-Tammam-Fulcher (VTF) type, which can be combined according to the situation. The Arrhenius equation, for instance, can be utilized to model the effect of temperature on the speed of chemical reactions in polymers. The Arrhenius equation is as follows. σ = A T - 1 exp - E a R T σ is the ionic conductivity of polymer electrolyte, E a is the activation energy, and A is the preexponential factor. The Arrhenius equation describes the relationship between ion conductivity and temperature. However, the Arrhenius equation has great limitations due to the complexity of ion transport in polymers. Then Vogel-Tammam-Fulcher proposed the VTF equation [67]. σ = 1 2 A T exp - E a T - T 0 The ionic conductivity of the polymer electrolyte is σ, the glass transition temperature is T 0 , E a is the activation energy, and A is the preexponential factor. When the temperature T is less than the glass transition temperature T 0, the relationship between the ion conductivity and the temperature conforms to the Arrhenius equation; otherwise, it conforms to the VTF equation. 3 Design strategies for composite solid electrolytes According to their preparation methods, composite solid electrolytes can be categorized into three types: layered composite electrolytes, physical composite electrolytes, and chemical composite solid electrolytes. Layered composite solid electrolytes are prepared through a direct delamination process of polymer and inorganic solid electrolytes or via the superposition of different composite electrolytes [68–70]. Meanwhile, the physical composite solid electrolytes can be obtained by mechanically mixing the polymer and the inorganic solid electrolytes or filling the polymer in the porous inorganic solid electrolyte framework [71–74]. Lastly, chemical composite solid electrolytes are produced through in-situ polymerization of polymer and inorganic solid electrolytes [75–78]. Table S1 provides a summary of the ionic conductivity and lithium-ion transference numbers of different composite solid electrolytes. It is worth noting that the performance of the composite solid electrolytes has improved significantly in contrast to that of the polymer solid electrolytes, reaching gains of up to several orders of magnitude. 3.1 Layered composite solid electrolytes Layered composite electrolytes offer an effective solution to the problem of high resistance caused by solid–solid contact while retaining the high mechanical strength of inorganic solid electrolytes, thus inhibiting the formation of lithium dendrites. This type of electrolyte can also address the issue of electrolyte reduction when in direct contact with lithium metal. The advantages of multi-layered structures can be leveraged to achieve better stability with metal lithium and meet high-voltage stability requirements of the cathode. First of all, the point contact of inorganic solid electrolytes can be improved to continuous surface contact by cascading polymer solid electrolytes on both sides of inorganic solid electrolytes, so as to reduce the interfacial resistance. Fan et al. prepared a PEO-based polymer solid electrolyte on both sides of the LLZO solid electrolyte to form a PEO-LLZTO-PEO sandwich composite solid electrolyte [79]. The PEO layer enhances electrode interface contact, increases lithium-ion deposition sites, promotes uniform lithium nucleation, and effectively inhibits the formation of lithium dendrites. This sandwich electrolyte demonstrates stable cycling behavior for 700 h under a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 at 90 °C (Fig. 5 a). Secondly, the layered structure can effectively inhibit the electrolyte reduction when in direct contact with lithium metal. For instance, PEO and PAN can also be added on both sides to solve the instability of LATP to lithium metal (Fig. 5b) [80]. As a result, NCM622/Li batteries exhibit a high capacity retention of 89% after 120 cycles under 0.5C along with a high Coulombic efficiency of over 99.5%. Besides, layered structure can also help to suppress the formation of lithium dendrites by means high mechanical strength of inorganic solid electrolyte. Sun’s group obtained “ceramic-in-polymer” (CIP) and “polymer-in-ceramic” (PIC) electrolyte by adding LLZO of different particle sizes and content to PEO (Fig. 5c) [81], CIP has a conductivity of up to 1.6 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature and PIC has a tensile strength of up to 12.7 MPa. CIP-PIC-CIP sandwich composite electrolyte not only ensures high conductivity, but also achieves high mechanical strength, which effectively prevents lithium dendrite from piercing the electrolyte and causing short circuit. The assembled Li symmetric cell is stable for 400 h at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 (30 °C). Finally, CPEs with a layered architecture can also help to meet the requirement of operation for ASSLBs under high-voltage. An asymmetric multilayer composite solid electrolyte was designed by Guo et al. to incorporate PEO/LiBOB and PEO/LLZO in the first and second layers respectively, achieving improved interface contact with the cathode and high mechanical strength with conductivity [82]. Stable cycling has been observed for over 2000 h with a capacity of 155.1 mA h g−1 at a rate of 0.2C and 90.2% retention after 200 cycles. Although layered composite solid electrolytes have a wide range of potential applications and can help to address various practical issues, they also possess several significant drawbacks. Firstly, the production of multilayer solid electrolytes requires a complicated manufacturing process, which can be time-consuming and expensive. Secondly, the addition of extra layers of solid electrolytes increases the number of interface contacts, and when the interface contacts are less than optimal, it can result in an increase in interface impedance and hindered lithium-ion transport. Lastly, the use of additional layers of solid electrolytes adds to the total weight of the battery, in turn leading to a reduction in its energy density. Therefore, despite their advantageous properties, the limitations and technical challenges of layered composite solid electrolytes need to be carefully considered before practical application is attempted. 3.2 Physical composite solid electrolytes 3.2.1 Nanoparticles Composite solid electrolytes (CSE) are used in electrochemical devices due to their good mechanical stability, flexibility and high ionic conductivity. One simple and efficient method of improving lithium-ion conductivity is to use active inorganic electrolyte particles to provide fast lithium-ion channels [83,84]. Inorganic solid electrolytes can be classified according to morphology, such as 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanowires, 2D nanosheets and 3D frameworks. The physical composite solid electrolytes can be prepared by either uniformly dispersing nano inorganic solid electrolytes in the polymer matrix or by impregnating the polymer into the inorganic filler skeleton. The simplest way to prepare composite electrolytes is by mechanically mixing the polymer with the inorganic filler in a solvent. Wang’s group [83] reported a LiAlSiO4 enhanced PEO-based polymer solid electrolyte, where LiAlSiO4 can significantly decrease the melting transition temperature of CSE, thus the ionic conductivity of electrolyte will be enhanced to a certain content (Fig. 6 a). Consequently, LFP/Li batteries exhibit a high discharge capacity of 130 mA h g−1 even at 4C rate, along with a high capacity retention rate of 91.74% after 500 cycles at 1C under 60 °C. Xu et al. [85] prepared composite electrolytes by mixing Li10GeP2S12 particles with PEO. The highest ionic conductivity of the electrolytes was 1.21 × 10−3 S cm−1 (80 °C), and the electrochemical window was 0–5.7 V. LiFePO4/Li battery has higher capacity retention (92.5% after 50 cycles at 60 °C). The current densities of 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C and 1C reach the capacity of 158, 148, 138 and 99 mA h g−1. However, inorganic fillers prepared by this method often have poor compatibility with polymers, resulting in the absence of synergistic effects. Modification of the surface of inorganic fillers can improve lithium-ion transport channels. For example, Park et al. manufactured composite solid electrolytes of polyvinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropylene and Li2.87La0.13Ti3.12O8 (LLTO) modified with a SiO2 buffer layer (Fig. 6b) [46]. The composite solid electrolytes showed excellent lithium dendrite inhibition ability and cycled stably for more than 1800 h at a current density of 0.48 mA cm−2. The assembled LiCoO2 battery still had a capacity retention of up to 80.5% after cycling for 500 cycles at a high rate of 0.5C. In addition to improving the ionic conductivity of CSEs, researchers continue to develop methods to extend battery life. One such method is the use of self-repairing polymers, which can heal and play a self-repairing role in batteries. Fatty acid-based polymers have strong viscosity and can adhere tightly to the surface of lithium metal, promoting the homogenization of surface lithium-ion flux and inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrite. Liu et al. used fatty acid polymers and Li6.4La3Zr1.4Nb0.6O12 (LLZNO) nanoparticles to prepare composite electrolytes with self-repairing function (Fig. 6c) [86]. The lithium symmetrical battery based on this electrolyte showed excellent cycle stability under a current density of 3 mA cm−2 and 10 mA cm−2, even under the ultra-high current density of 20 mA cm−2. Although the addition of nanoparticles to polymers to increase the conductivity of composite solid-state electrolytes has proven to be a simple and valid method, with the increase of nanoparticle content, the agglomerated particles will not form an effective ion transport between each other and lead to a decrease in the efficiency of Li+ transport. In addition, loosely packed nanoparticles are not sufficient to provide sufficiently high ionic conductivity, so simply increasing the content of nanoparticles is not effective in improving the conductivity of composite solid-state electrolytes. Overall, various methods have been developed to improve the performance of composite solid electrolytes, such as the use of inorganic electrolytes and the modification of the surface of inorganic fillers, as well as introducing self-repairing polymers to extend battery life. 3.2.2 Nanowires In the field of solid-state batteries, one-dimensional nanowire fillers have shown to be promising materials due to their larger contact area with the polymer electrolyte and high aspect ratios. Electrospinning is the most widely used method for the preparation of one-dimensional nanowire fillers [87–89]. For instance, He et al. [90] prepared LLZO precursor by electrospinning, and the LLZO nanowires were obtained after sintering. The addition of PEO and LiTFSI can also build lithium-ion pathways in the composite solid electrolyte, ensuring efficient ion transport during long cycles. This contributed to the uniform deposition of lithium dendrites, which hinder the formation of lithium dendrites, and the increased ionic conductivity and mechanical strength of the solid electrolyte composite (Fig. 7 a). The assay of a lithium symmetrical battery showed it cycled stably for over 1050 h under a high current density of 1 mA cm−2. The ordered LLZO nanowires (Fig. 7b), according to Ding, can conduct lithium ions faster than randomly distributed nanowires [91]. The prepared NCA/Li battery had an ultra-low internal resistance of only 87 Ω and high coulomb efficiency and discharge capacity compared with commercial liquid electrolyte battery. Mai et al. [92] proposed a gradient electrospinning strategy for preparing LLTO nanotubes, which differ from traditional nanoparticles and nanowires (Fig. 7c). Nanotubes composed of interconnected nanoparticles forming many pores and channels provide a continuous lithium-ion transport path. The composite solid electrolyte based on the LLTO and PAN nanotube structure has an ionic conductivity of up to 3.6 × 10–4 S cm−1 at room temperature. The prepared lithium symmetrical battery had an overpotential of only 30mv at a circuit density of 0.05 mA cm−2 at 25 °C. The LFP battery maintained a capacity retention rate of over 90% after 100 cycles at 0.5C. Lastly, Kang's group [87] reported a 3D spiny AlF3/Mullite heterostructure nanofiber with a strong binding energy with anions and wide electrochemical stability window. It reduced nucleation overpotential of lithium during cycling and suppressed the growth of lithium dendrites, resulting in stable cycling performance at different area capacities and great cyclic stability of LFP/Li batteries. Compared with nanoparticles, nanowires can provide a short-ordered ion transport pathway and form more polymer/filler interface to enhance the ionic conductivity of composite solid electrolyte. However, there are almost no naturally occurring nanowires that can be used directly to prepare composite solid-state electrolytes. Nowadays, the preparation of nanowires mainly relies on the template method and electrospinning remains the primary method for obtaining nanowire fillers, the process is currently inefficient and unsuitable for large-scale production. 3.2.3 Nanosheets In the design of composite solid electrolytes, scientists have turned to nature and life for inspiration. Hu et al. [93] applied tile-and-grout patterns to create a composite solid electrolyte (Fig. 7d) using LLZO ceramic sheets connected by styrene-butadiene copolymer (SBC) through 3D printing. The LLZO sheets facilitated fast lithium-ion transport, while the SBC grid served as a flexible buffer layer to minimize stress transferred to the garnet sheets. The resulting electrolyte film exhibited outstanding extensibility, with 220% strain and ultimate tensile strength of 5.12 MPa. Moreover, it demonstrated excellent stability in static and electrochemical cycles, thanks to its high lithium-ion conductivity, mechanical strength, and flexibility. Although 3D printing is a novel preparation method for composite electrolytes, it has not yet received much attention from researchers. Inspired by the nacre structure, Yang et al. [94] proposed a nacre-like layered composite solid-state electrolyte (Fig. 7e). The nacre-like electrolyte had superior properties, including a higher fracture strain of 1.1% compared to 0.13% for pure ceramic electrolyte and a larger ultimate bending modulus of 7.8 GPa than the pure polymer electrolyte's 20 MPa. When used in an assembled LiFePO4 cell, the nacre-like electrolyte showed 92% capacity retention after 300 cycles at 0.5C, and there was no significant capacity loss after applying a 10 N load. In contrast, both pure PEA and LAGP assembled cells experienced sharp capacity decay. Furthermore, nanosheets have the potential to provide fast and continuous lithium-ion transport paths because of their interconnected structure. Despite this potential, there is only limited research on nanosheets. The main limitation of nanosheets is the inadequacy of the preparation process for large-scale production. Thus, future research on using nanosheets as active fillers should focus primarily on developing synthesis technologies and dispersion methods. 3.2.4 Three-dimensional network Several studies have explored the use of polymer solid electrolytes to create 3D composite frameworks, which can improve the transport of lithium ions. Polymer solid electrolytes fill the 3D framework, creating continuous and complete 3D channels [95,96], without agglomeration between active fillers. The longer fast lithium-ion transport path achieved by this method leads to faster transport of lithium-ion in the 3D framework composite solid electrolytes. Compared to other forms of active fillers, this process results in composite electrolytes with improved electrochemical performance and mechanical strength. To address the issue of inconsistent lithium coordination brought about by agglomeration of traditional low-dimensional active fillers in polymer electrolytes, Yu et al. designed a 3D LLTO nano-framework structure derived from hydrogel (Fig. 8 a) [97]. This structure allowed lithium-ion to achieve continuous 3D transport on the interface between the prepared 3D LLTO framework and PEO, thereby raising the ionic conductivity of the prepared composite electrolytes to 8.8 × 10−5 S cm−1 at room temperature. This approach offers a new way of preparing 3D framework composite electrolytes. The 3D framework is conventionally obtained through sintering, but this method often results in a fragile structure. Scholars have been exploring ways to address this issue; Li et al. dispersed LATP nanoparticles into the DMF solution of PAN and then electrospun it to prepare the 3D LATP/PAN framework [98]. The addition of PAN alleviated the brittleness problem of the inorganic solid electrolyte itself. The composite solution of PEO and LiTFSI was cast on the 3D LATP/PAN framework and dried to produce the 3D framework composite solid electrolyte. This method effectively solves the problem of the reduction of LATP in direct contact with lithium metal, with the prepared composite solid electrolyte remaining stable after 15 days of direct contact with lithium metal. However, the ion transport capacity of the framework is weak as only the polymer and inorganic fillers in the framework are present, without lithium salt. To address this issue, a 3D ion conduction network with conductive oxide increase was developed [99]. This process involved the electrospinning of LLZO nanoparticles with a mixed polymer electrolyte (PVDF-PEO with LiTFSI) to form nanofibers, which were then densely packed into the polymer nanofibers (Fig. 8b). This method further optimizes the transport path of lithium ions. The conventional process of preparing composite solid electrolytes has been criticized for leaving residual solvents, which can result in some unknown side reactions during battery cycles. To address this issue, a solvent-free method was proposed [100]. This method involved obtaining the LLZTO/PTFE 3D framework by mixing LLZTO nanoparticles with PTFE in a certain ratio and pressing it through a nylon mesh (Fig. 8c). The composite solid electrolyte was then obtained by dipping the LLZTO/PTFE 3D framework into the molten SN and LiTFSI solution, and then removing it from the solution. This process resulted in a prepared composite solid electrolyte with an ionic conductivity of 1.2 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature as well as high discharge specific capacities of batteries and desirable cyclic stabilities. The use of 3D network skeleton to enhance composite solid electrolytes is an effective way to solve the problem of nanofiller agglomeration and achieve long-range ordered ion transport channels, thereby facilitating efficient ion diffusion. However, the preparation process of the 3D network skeleton is arduous and relatively demanding. Future research should focus on developing simpler methods to construct 3D skeletons and investigating systematically the influence of precursor species, composition, and proportion on the 3D morphology, skeleton size, pore size, connectivity, and other properties of the framework, with the aim of achieving controllable 3D skeleton fabrication. 3.3 Chemical composite solid electrolytes Both the layered composite solid electrolytes and the physical composite solid electrolytes are essentially filled with inorganic solid electrolyte nanofillers into the polymer through a mechanical mixing method. However, the most serious problem in the composite solid electrolyte prepared by this method is the dispersion of nano active fillers. Active fillers are extremely prone to agglomeration through a simple mixing method, resulting in a decrease in the content of the composite conductive interface and a decrease in conductivity. Moreover, the internal inorganic solid electrolytes have poor compatibility with the polymer electrolytes. Therefore, it is urgent to solve the problem of agglomeration of active fillers and compatibility with polymer solid electrolytes. Scholars have put forward the concept of chemical composite solid electrolyte, which is formed by in-situ polymerization in the battery. The compatibility of inorganic solid electrolytes and polymer solid electrolytes is well solved by in-situ polymerization. Compared with the composite solid electrolytes prepared by the traditional mechanical mixing method, the ionic conductivity of the composite solid electrolytes is also improved by an order of magnitude. There are two commonly used in-situ polymerization methods for the preparation of composite solid electrolytes, radical polymerization and gelator polymerization. 3.3.1 Radical polymerization Radical polymerization is the production of free radicals through an initiator, which is initiated by heating or UV-light [104]. The whole polymerization takes place in the organic phase, and the inorganic filler hardly participates in the reaction. Zhang et al. [101] combined the idea of rigid and flexible with the technology of in-situ polymerization to design an asymmetric composite solid electrolyte. In the process of in-situ polymerization, the natural deposition of LLZO was used to form a high mechanical strength natural precipitated layer of LLZO on the negative side to inhibit the formation of lithium dendrites, while maintaining good interfacial compatibility on the positive side (Fig. 9 a). The prepared composite solid electrolyte has a conductivity of up to 8.43 × 10−4 S cm−1, which is close to the conductivity of traditional liquid electrolytes of 10−3 S cm−1. The assembled NCM532 battery has an initial discharge specific capacity of 149.1 mA h g−1 at room temperature. The lithium symmetrical battery can cycle stably for more than 600 h at the current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. In addition, compounding a carefully designed 3D framework with a polymer solid electrolyte is also a current research hotspot. Wen [102] designed a 3D LAGP framework with many vertical pores through the ice template method (Fig. 9b). The vertical pores can ensure that lithium ions can be transported vertically with the shortest transmission path. The 3D LAGP is combined with SN by in-situ thermal polymerization technology. The composite solid electrolyte exhibits a conductivity of up to 1.17 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 30 °C, and the lithium-ion transference number reaches 0.77. The critical current density is as high as 1 mA cm−2. The capacity retention rate of the assembled NCM532 half-cell reaches 90% after being cycled at 0.2C for 100 cycles. 3.3.2 Gelator polymerization Gelator polymerization is the in-situ assembly of small molecular organic compounds with inorganic solid electrolytes through hydrogen bonds, π-π bonds and other interactions to form a three-dimensional network structure to form composite solid electrolytes. In order to solve the problem of compatibility between the inorganic solid electrolytes and the polymer. Zhang's group used (3-chloropropyl) trimethoxysilane (CTMS) as coupling agent, LGPS and PEG formed chemical bonds through in-situ coupling reaction inspired by hydrogen bond and lithium bond (Fig. 9c) [103]. A uniform mixed solid electrolyte PEO/PEG-3LGPS, with room temperature ionic conductivity of 9.83 × 10−4 S cm−1 was obtained by adding PEO and LITFSI. The ionic conductivity of PEO/PEG-3LGPS obtained by mechanical mixing is 2.42 × 10−4 S cm−1. In addition, the symmetrical lithium battery of PEO/PEG-3LGPS can cycle stably for 6700 h at room temperature. The initial charging capacity of LTO/PEO/PEG-3LGPS/Li battery is 141.8 mA h g−1. The ionic conductivity and mechanical strength of the composite electrolyte prepared by in-situ polymerization were improved. However, there is still a lack of research on the degree and way of polymerization. 3.4 Ion transport mechanism of composite solid electrolytes Ionic conductivity is the most important index for evaluating the performance of composite solid electrolytes. Therefore, the lithium-ion transport mechanism in composite solid electrolytes deserves a high degree of attention. At present, there are three main views on the lithium-ion transport mechanism in composite solid electrolytes as shown in Fig. 10 : (1) transport of Lithium-ion by Inorganic solid electrolytes, (2) transport of Lithium-ion by Polymer electrolytes, and (3) transport of Lithium-ion by Organic-inorganic composite interface. The mechanism of interface conduction has gradually been recognized by people. In the early studies, the inorganic electrolyte fillers in the composite electrolytes generally played a role in reducing the crystallinity of polymers and providing a fast lithium-ion pathway. Hu studied the transference path of lithium ion in LLZO particle-PEO (LITFSI) composite electrolyte by 6Li NMR [105]. When the content of LLZO is low, LLZO plays a role in reducing the crystallinity of the polymer. Lithium ion is mainly transported through the polymer and very little through LLZO. However, when the content of LLZO increases to a critical value, LLZO particles will connect with each other to form a percolation network to make lithium-ion transport through LLZO (Fig. 11 a). These two transport mechanisms have also been confirmed in composite electrolytes filled with other inorganic solid electrolytes. However, further studies have found that there is a space charge layer (Fig. 11b) with about 3 nm of the LLZO/PEO interface [106]. The formation of the space charge layer is due to the fact that LLZO nanoparticles come into contact with PEO, the driving force from the interface chemical potential will drive lithium ions to migrate to the surface at the regular LLZO lattice position, resulting in the accumulation of positively charged ions on the surface and negatively charged vacancies in the lattice. It finally reached a new equilibrium state with the further progress of the transference process, leaving high concentration of lithium ion and low concentration of vacancy. A continuous path can be formed when the space charge regions are connected to each other, which provides a new dynamic way for ion conduction. This is the first time to discover the mechanism and principle of interface conduction. There is evidence that the organic–inorganic interface provides fast lithium ion channels in different systems of composite electrolytes [107]. But different conclusions were obtained when the transference path of lithium ion in LLZO-PEO was also studied by NMR [108]. Zheng et al. find that lithium ions are inclined to maximize the fraction of LLZO in their diffusion pathway, and minimize the fraction of the interface or PEO polymer (Fig. 11c). It is proved that lithium ions are conducted through LLZO instead of PEO/LLZO interface or PEO electrolyte, which contradicts the former conclusion. This opposite conclusion seems to appear only when LLZO is the filler. Guo thinks that the controversial ion transport mechanism of LLZO (interfacial transport or bulk transport) is related to interfacial Li2CO3 [109]. He found that 20wt% LLZO particles could weaken the crystallinity of the polymer and increase the ionic conductivity by improving the segmental motion of the PEO chain (Fig. 11d). Moreover, the percolation effect can construct a continuous interface channel between LLZO particles and PEO. However, the ionic conductivity of Li2CO3 is very poor, which hinders the rapid transference of lithium ions along the interface. When the LLZTO content exceeds the percolation threshold, the interfacial lithium transport pathway is hindered, which leads to the decrease of ionic conductivity. At this point, Li2CO3 hinders the transport of Li between PEO matrix and LLZO block. With a further increase of the amount of LLZO, the accumulated LLZO particles can block the movement of the polymer chain and reduce the lithium-ion conductivity in the PEO region. At this time, lithium ions tend to transport through the LLZTO bulk phase as well as the Li2CO3 passivation layer will hinder the transport. So far, the interfacial transport mechanism in composite electrolytes has been widely agreed. However, the above observations were carried out below the glass transition temperature of the polymer. The polymer has high ionic conductivity above the glass transition temperature. Whether the lithium-ion transport mechanism is the same as at room temperature remains to be explored. In addition, the morphology of inorganic fillers significantly affects the ion transport within composite solid electrolytes. As is well known, ion transport in polymer electrolytes occurs primarily in the amorphous regions, where lithium ions are transported by complexation and decomplexation with polymer chain segments. Traditional nano-particle fillers simply decrease the crystallinity of the polymer and provide a non-continuous polymer/nano-particle composite interface for Li+ transport. In contrast, nano-wire fillers not only greatly reduce the crystallinity of the polymer, but also create a short-range ordered continuous Li+ pathway along the polymer/nano-wire interface, enabling rapid ion transport and higher ionic conductivity in the composite solid electrolyte. Furthermore, nano-plate fillers themselves have larger surface areas and can significantly increase the area of the polymer/nano-plate composite interface, providing a continuous two-dimensional lithium-ion transport interface that ensures superior lithium-ion transport performance. However, when the filler content is too high, nano-particles, nano-wires, and nano-plates will all aggregate, leading to a decrease in the ionic conductivity of the composite solid electrolyte and inefficient Li+ transport. Therefore, three-dimensional networks of inorganic solid electrolytes have been developed to solve the filler aggregation problem and provide long-range ordered Li+ transport pathways, enabling rapid Li+ transport. In summary, there are three lithium-ion transference paths in the composite electrolyte, so the ionic conductivity can be improved by improving these three aspects. In summary, there are three lithium-ion transference paths in the composite electrolyte, so the ionic conductivity can be improved by improving these three aspects. The first is to improve the ion transport capacity of the polymer, which needs to reduce the crystallinity of the polymer and improve the ability of free movement of the chain segment. Liu uses the inevitable impurities Li2CO3 and LiOH on the surface of LLZO as initiators to induce the ring-opening reaction of EC to form ether oligomers, which act as plasticizers to reduce the crystallinity of PEO and maintain its amorphous state through hydrogen bonds [110]. The highest conductivity of the composite electrolyte at room temperature is 1.43 × 10− 3 S cm−1. Secondly, the interfacial transport is improved by increasing the number of interfaces or increasing the ionic conductivity of the interface. Chen used coaxial electrospinning and electrostatic spray to prepare composite electrolytes with a large number of interfaces [111]. Electrospinning PAN nanowires and electrostatic spraying LLZO nanoparticles at the same time. Then immersed in anhydrous ethanol solution of LiClO4, the composite electrolyte with high ceramic content (74.6 wt%), high interfacial number and high ionic conductivity (1.18 × 10−3 S cm−1) was prepared. It is one method to increase the ionic conductivity simply by increasing the number of interfaces, and another method is to improve the ionic conductivity of the interface by optimizing the lithium coordination environment. For example, using the ring-opening polymerization of DOL on lithium alloy, an artificial SEI was constructed between lithium alloy and PEO matrix, which showed much higher ionic conductivity than that of inorganic filler interface [112]. The third method is to improve the performance of inorganic fillers, which can promote the improvement of composite electrolyte ionic conductivity, the expansion of electrochemical window and the ability to inhibit lithium dendrites. 4 Interface engineering for composite solid electrolytes While a considerable amount of research has been conducted to enhance the ionic conductivity of composite electrolytes, the interface issue should not be overlooked. Despite the fact that composite electrolytes offer a more stable interface than inorganic solid electrolytes, and can effectively mitigate issues related to lithium instability, some problems still need to be resolved. Specifically, the primary problem lies in the stability of the positive electrode, as well as the interface reactions with the negative electrode and lithium dendrite (Fig. 12 ). These concerns with composite electrolytes must be addressed to improve their performance for practical applications. 4.1 Interface problems with the anode 4.1.1 Interface reaction with the anode The instability of the interface is a key limitation in the development of high specific energy lithium metal batteries due to the low electrochemical potential and high reactivity of lithium metal [113–115]. The interface reaction layer between the solid electrolyte and lithium metal can be characterized as thermodynamically stable interfaces, reactive mixed-ionic/electronic conducting interphases and metastable solid-electrolyte interphases depending on the interface's thermodynamic and kinetic stability [116]. Generally, the interface layer between the solid electrolyte and lithium metal consists of the latter two. On the negative electrode side of organic–inorganic composite electrolytes, three types of interfacial reactions occur. The first reaction involves lithium salt and lithium metal, while the second reaction involves polymer and lithium metal, which is the most reactive. The last reaction is between inorganic solid electrolyte and lithium metal. Upon contact with the electrolyte component and lithium metal in the composite electrolyte, organic and inorganic lithium compounds are formed, and the reaction can differ based on the type of polymer and lithium salt used. For instance, using AFM and FTIR spectroscopy, Maryline et al. discovered in a PEO-LiSO3CF3 system that CF3 radicals are formed on the lithium metal surface, which can seize the hydrogen atom in the polymer framework, followed by the lithium atom further destructing the C-O bond in the polymer to form Li-O-R type compounds [117]. In PVDF-LiX (X = FSI−, TFSI−, ClO4 −) systems, the interface products include LiF, Li2S, Li2O, and Li2CO3/LiOH when X = FSI−, and LiF, Li2O, and Li2CO3/LiOH when X = TFSI− [118]. The in situ formed inorganic-rich SEI has excellent stability and can effectively inhibit the growth of Li dendrites. As a result, the Li/Li symmetric cells can cycle stably for more than 2000 h at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2, and the assembled LCO/Li cells have almost no capacity degradation even after 200 cycles at a current density of 0.15 mA cm−2 at room temperature. This also fully demonstrates the importance of constructing a stable SEI to enhance the stability of the anode interface. Due to the strong reductivity of lithium metal, the redox reaction between polymer and lithium is the primary reaction. According to the frontier molecular orbital theory [119], LUMO energy levels of electrolyte components represent their electron absorption capacity [120]. If the LUMO energy level of the electrolyte component is lower than the electrochemical potential of the lithium metal, lithium metal tends to transfer electrons to the LUMO of the electrolyte component, initiating a spontaneous reduction reaction at the interface, and generating a SEI film on the surface of the lithium anode (Fig. 13 a) [121]. The LUMO energy level of the polymer is generally higher than that of lithium salt (Fig. 13b), and inorganic elements come from the lithium salts. In general, non-dense inorganic compounds form in the outer layer. Nevertheless, the SEI film formed by lithium salt is crucial, and the current research on composite electrolytes uses LiTFSI and LiFSI because of their high ionic conductivity and high chemical stability. However, the film-forming properties of LiFSI and LiTFSI on the surface of lithium metal are distinct, with SO2F, FSI− group being more reactive, and the decomposition LiF as the main product [122]. Therefore, the film-forming performance of LiFSI at the lithium metal surface is better, protecting the negative electrode of lithium metal and inhibiting dendrite growth more effectively [123]. In order to enhance the ionic conductivity, electrochemical window, and other properties of composite electrolytes, a variety of inorganic solid electrolytes that are unstable to metal lithium can be added as fillers. Although these fillers still undergo interfacial reactions with lithium metal, the presence of the polymer ensures that these reactions are not indefinite. For instance, using TOF-SIMS combined with XPS, Goodenough's group [124] analyzed the interface between a PEO/LSTZ composite electrolyte and metallic lithium. They discovered that perovskite LSTZ reacts with lithium metal to form transition metal compounds (LiTaO3 and SrO), while PEO and LiTFSI are decomposed into several lithium compounds over the course of cycling (LiF, Li2O, Li3N, Li2CO3, and Li2S). The resulting intermediate layer consists of lithium compounds in the outer layer and transition metal compounds close to the electrolyte in the inner layer. This layer is an effective way to improve the wettability of the lithium metal and inhibit the formation of Li dendrites in the repeated cycle. Symmetric lithium batteries employing this PEO/LSTZ electrolyte exhibit stable stripping/plating behaviors without significant lithium dendrite growth over 700 h. In addition, the symmetric cells can cycle even at high current densities up to 0.6 mA cm−2 with low overpotentials of 310 mV, demonstrating fast charge transfer and stable interfaces between the PEO/LSTZ composite electrolyte and metallic lithium. Meanwhile, interfacial reactions can also occur between the polymer and the filler. Jürgen Janek et al. added Li6PS5Cl to PEO20: LiTFSI to prepare a composite electrolyte [125]. The interfacial reaction between Li6PS5Cl and PEO20: LiTFSI in the composite electrolyte takes place even before lithium metal is introduced. The decomposition of PEO20: LiTFSI yields -COOR and LiF, while the inorganic solid electrolyte Li6PS5Cl is decomposed into Li3PO4 and (-Sx0-). These decomposition products affect the formation of a solid electrolyte intermediate phase where the resistance is reduced to 3.3 Ω cm2, compared to 5.8 Ω cm2 for PEO20: LiTFSI alone. During the 15 min of the lithium symmetrical battery cycle, LITFSI is reduced to produce LiF and Li x S y O z , while Li6PS5Cl is decomposed into (-Sx0-) and eventually Li x S y O z and (-Sx0-) form Li2S. After 20 min, the decomposition reaction rate of LiTFSI and Li6PS5Cl decreases until an SEI composed primarily of LiF and Li2S is formed (Fig. 13d). Although interfacial reactions in composite electrolytes can have beneficial effects, researchers should focus on ways to control these reactions to stabilize the interface and inhibit lithium dendrites. In the future, it will be important to develop methods to control these reactions to create more stable interfaces for better electrolyte stability. 4.1.2 Lithium dendrites Early studies hypothesized that high mechanical strength inorganic solid electrolytes could effectively hinder lithium dendrite growth. However, numerous experimental findings contradict these claims, and demonstrate that the use of inorganic solid electrolytes can actually accelerate the formation of dendrites when compared to traditional liquid lithium-ion batteries [126]. Recent research indicates that high electronic conductivity is the primary cause of lithium dendrite proliferation in inorganic solid electrolytes [127]. Lithium dendrites grow via defects, pores, and grain boundaries present in the inorganic solid electrolytes, leading to battery failure [128]. Despite the fact that the mechanical strength of polymer electrolytes is lower than that of inorganic solid electrolytes, they are capable of forming stronger connections with lithium metal, resulting in a uniform lithium-ion flux that inhibits dendrite growth. The downside, however, is the polymer's lower strength, making it more susceptible to penetration by dendrites [129]. The mechanical properties of the polymer electrolytes and lithium metal impurities both play a crucial role in lithium dendrite formation within polymer solid electrolytes [130,131]. Lithium dendrite growth in composite electrolytes can be divided into two stages: nucleation and growth. Combining the benefits of inorganic and organic solid electrolytes, composite electrolytes can effectively prevent both stages of dendrite formation. During the nucleation stage, the polymer improves electrode contact with traditional inorganic solid electrolytes. Simultaneously, the polymer is capable of accommodating lithium metal expansion during cycling, ensuring that the composite electrolyte remains in close contact with lithium metal. Secondly, an interfacial reaction produces a dense, high ionic conductivity SEI film that uniformly deposits lithium ions on the negative side. Third, the composite electrolyte's low electronic conductivity (less than 10−10 S cm−1) prevents Li+ from being reduced to Li0 by electrons. Li+ diffusion often results in electron reduction in inorganic solid electrolytes [132]. Finally, the transference number of lithium ions is a critical parameter for predicting the nucleation of lithium dendrites. According to the Brissot and Chazalviel model [133,134], when the anion can move freely in the electrolyte, it will concentrate on the positive side, while the lithium ion will migrate to the negative side, leading to an anion-cation concentration disparity. This difference can result in a local space charge buildup on the negative electrode surface, leading to a powerful electric field and dendrite nucleation. The starting time of lithium nucleation can be predicted by Sand's time based on this model. τ = π D ( e C 0 2 J t a ) 2 t a = μ a μ Li + + μ a D is the diffusion coefficient; E is the elementary charge; μ Li + and μ A is lithium ion and anion transference capacity; Ta is anion transference number; C0 is the initial concentration of lithium salt; J is the current density. When the number of anion transference in the electrolyte approaches zero, the occurrence time of lithium dendrite tends to infinity. In other words, the emergence of lithium dendrite will be indefinitely delayed. Therefore, it is possible to limit the movement of anions inside the solid composite electrolytes to reduce the space charge effect to induce the formation of lithium dendrites. The composite electrolyte has a higher lithium-ion transference number relative to the polymer as shown in Table S1. In the context of lithium dendrite propagation, inorganic solid electrolyte fillers are commonly believed to possess high mechanical strength that can limit the growth of dendrites in a polymer matrix. However, it is noteworthy that the polymer component in composite electrolytes can also influence the growth of lithium dendrites, a phenomenon not observed in pure polymer electrolytes. A research study by Pan et al. [135] examined the respective effects of inorganic fillers and polymers in composite electrolytes. In particular, they assembled four different types of lithium symmetrical batteries, each with varying LATP and polymer content. The results showed that while the pure polymer electrolyte battery ran for only 2,600 min, the other three composite electrolyte batteries had significantly longer operated times of 20,000, 10,800, and 12,300 min, respectively. This shows that the growth of lithium dendrite is not hindered and it is easy to penetrate the polymer electrolyte. The dense inorganic layer in the composite electrolyte can be used as a physical barrier to limit the free growth of lithium dendrites. However, the different short circuit time of electrolyte with the same LATP content indicates that the inorganic layer is not the only decisive factor affecting the growth of lithium dendrite. Polymers also play an important role in inhibiting dendrite growth in composite electrolytes. The more the inorganic solid electrolyte content in the composite electrolyte, the stronger the ability to resist the growth of lithium dendrites as a physical barrier. However, with the increase content of inorganic fillers, interaction between nanoscale fillers can lead to agglomeration of fillers, which means a significant reduction in the number of polymer/filler composite conductive interfaces and causes a poor Li+ transport pathway. So, properties such as ion conductivity are not necessarily the best. Therefore, how to balance the ionic conductivity and the ability to inhibit lithium dendrites needs to continue to be explored. Understanding the ability of materials to inhibit lithium dendrite growth often involves assembling lithium symmetrical batteries and conducting several types of tests. One such test is the critical current density, in which a current is applied to a battery for deposition and stripping cycles, increasing in intensity until short circuiting occurs. The maximum current that a battery can sustain represents its critical current density. Constant current cycling is another test, in which a battery is subjected to a constant current density during a prolonged deposition and stripping cycle, monitoring changes in overpotential, impedance, and surface morphology after each cycle. Table S2 presents the cyclic performance of symmetric lithium batteries with different composite electrolytes. Most composite electrolytes have been stabled for up to 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 or 0.2 mA cm−2. However, little research exists into these cycles under high currents, which warrants future investigation. 4.2 Interface problems with cathode There are distinct interface problems between the positive electrode and the solid electrolyte, which vary depending on the type of solid electrolyte utilized. When using oxide-based solid electrolytes, lattice mismatching and large changes in electrode volume are common contact issues due to the high hardness of the material [136]. Meanwhile, sulfide-based solid electrolytes tend to form a space charge layer at the interface with the positive electrode, which adversely impacts interfacial resistance and performance (Fig. 14 a). This space charge layer results in a transference and redistribution of lithium ions, leading to changes in the P-S bond state of Li6PS5Cl at the interface. The high voltage compatibility of the electrolyte can be used as a measure of its ability to resist oxidation and decomposition in materials thermodynamics. In addition, according to the frontier orbitals theory, the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMO) of all components, including polymers, lithium salts, and additives, in the composite solid-state electrolyte must be lower than the HOMO of the positive electrode; otherwise, the component cannot exist stably and undergoes decomposition under the working voltage of the positive electrode material. Over time, the interface performance and electrochemical capacity gradually deteriorate due to a combination of negative factors, such as space charge layer, interface reaction, and interface mechanical failure [137]. The first contact with the positive electrode is the polymer in the composite electrolyte, the polymer can fill the gap between the inorganic solid electrolyte and the positive electrode. The polymer can be deformed according to the changing stress to ensure its close contact with the adjacent phase, so the problem of high resistance can be solved. However, the poor wettability of the composite electrolyte results in the lack of lithium-ion pathways in the positive electrode. Therefore, a conductive polymer is sometimes added to the positive electrode to prepare a composite positive electrode. However, different polymers have different binding abilities to positive electrode active materials. Chen et. al reported a Al2O3@NCM532 based composite cathode framework enhanced with PEO and Li salt, which greatly improves the interfacial stability between electrolyte and cathode. Therefore, modified batteries with this composite cathode framework exhibit a high initial discharge capacity of 150.6 mA h g−1 as well as a high capacity retention of 86.7% after 80 cycles at 0.2C under 55 °C. In addition, the binder contains rich polar groups (–OH, –COOH), which can also well stabilize the polymer matrix and avoid its decomposition under high voltage. Sun studied the application of several binders, including PEO, PVDF, carboxyl-rich polymer (CRP) binders (CMC and sodium alginate) in LCO batteries [138]. The surface of PEO-LCO electrode shows a very loose and porous structure. The surface of LCO particles is clear and there are no carbon black particles, which indicates that the binding ability of PEO is poor. However, for LCO electrodes based on CRP binder, the surface of LCO particles is covered with CRP binder. In other words, CRP binder acts as a coating on the surface of LCO particles. Many carbon-black particles appear on the surface of LCO particles, which means that CRP binder can firmly connect carbon particles to LCO particles. Therefore, CRP adhesive can not only maintain the integrity of the electrode, but also can be used as a coating material to protect the electrode/electrolyte interface (Fig. 14b). As a result, the capacity retention of the LCO/Li all-solid-state battery with CMC binder was 85% after 300 cycles, which was much higher than that of the PEO binder (40.1%) and the PVDF binder (46%), respectively. Moreover, after 1000 cycles, the capacity retention of the LCO/Li all-solid-state battery with CMC binder was still 59.7%, while that of the solid-state battery with PEO binder was only 6.7%. This shows the potential application of using binders with strong polar groups in high-voltage ASSLBs. PEO-based polymer electrolytes can avoid decomposition under high voltage, resulting in the formation of ultra-stable, high-performance 4 V all-solid-state batteries. Secondly, the polymer electrolyte is difficult to meet the requirements of low HOMO and high LUMO in the composite cathode, so the electrolyte is easy to oxidize and decompose. However, the electrolyte based on PEO and LiFePO4 cathode has good chemical and electrochemical stability. France even developed electric vehicles assembled with Li|PEO|LiFePO4 solid-state batteries, but the energy density is only 100 Wh kg−1. PEO polymer electrolytes are difficult to withstand more than 4 V voltage [142]. Sun's team explored whether the narrow electrochemical window of PEO is due to its main chain or end group [143]. It is found that the stable potential of PEO can be increased to 4.3 V by replacing the terminal-OH with-OCH3 (Fig. 14c), this makes it possible to match the solid-state electrolyte with the NCM532 high-voltage cathode material, and the assembled Li/Li symmetric cells can have an extended cycle life of up to 2500 h (0.2 mA cm2, 0.2 mA h cm2). Benefiting from the enhanced anode interfacial stability and the high voltage tolerance of the –OCH3 group, NCM532/Li pouch cell with an area capacity of 0.47 mA h cm2 demonstrates more than 90% capacity retention over 110 cycles in the 2.5–4.2 V (0.1C) operating voltage window. Therefore, the decomposition problems in polymer electrolytes also occur in composite electrolytes. The redox process is also related to the decomposition of lithium salts and the catalysis of electrodes, which accelerate the decomposition of polymers. Ma et al. [144] proved that the interaction between PEO and LiDFOB weakens after charge–discharge cycle by FTIR spectrum analysis. They observed the decomposition of Li salts by XPS analysis, indicating that the interaction between lithium salts and polymer matrix is one of the factors leading to the degradation of polymer solid electrolytes at high voltage. Nie et al. [145] proved that the catalysis of the electrode leads to the earlier decomposition of the polymer. The pure PEO will not show obvious gas production decomposition behavior until the voltage reaches 4.5 V. After the positive electrode of LCO was added to the battery, the gas production behavior of 4.2 V began to appear. According to the DFT calculation, they predicted that the electrolyte decomposition of PEO can be divided into three steps: first, due to the existence of LCO positive electrode, the oxygen in PEO is partially oxidized and the strength of C–H bond is weakened; then, the H proton is taken away by TFSI− to form hydrogenated HTFSI. Because HTFSI is a strong acid and highly corrosive to PEO and LCO, it will aggravate the formation of positive/electrolyte interface and the deterioration of battery performance. Finally, HTFSI will further spread to the negative electrode and react with lithium metal to produce hydrogen. In general, the polymer electrolyte or the polymer part of the composite electrolyte is unstable under high pressure. The addition of inorganic solid electrolytes to polymer electrolytes can significantly improve the electrochemical window. The electrochemical windows of various composite electrolytes are shown in the Table S3. Most of the electrochemical windows are larger than 4.2 V, which can match the high voltage electrolyte such as NCM. The electrochemical window of the composite electrolyte is usually determined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) by assembling a Li/CPE/SS battery. However, the measured electrochemical window is generally higher due to the small contact area, which is quite different from the experiment. Wang et al. [83] prepared CSEs with a wide electrochemical stability window up to 4.9 V by mixing LiAlSiO4 nanoparticles into PEO-based solid-state electrolytes. Nevertheless, LFP was selected as the cathode material in the actual electrochemical performance evaluation stage instead of the high-voltage NCM cathode or LCO cathode, etc., which also indicates that the measured electrochemical stability window is significantly higher than the actual value. Nowadays, the test method of the real electrochemical window is to use the composite electrode made of composite electrolyte and conductive carbon to realize the three-dimensional contact of electrolyte/electrode from the traditional two-dimensional contact. It can improve the contact area and reaction kinetics of the solid–solid interface, so the real electrochemical window of solid electrolyte can be measured. The window measured by this method is in good agreement with the results of thermodynamic calculation [146]. At present, the method to improve the electrochemical window of the composite electrolyte is mainly through the improvement of the polymer matrix. By raising the energy level of the polymer or using a polymer (PAN) that can withstand high voltage. It is also possible to adjust the matching of lithium salts and polymers. Oxidation stability of some common anions: AsF6 −>PF6 −>BF4 −>TFSI−>ClO4 −>BOB−. Both polymers and lithium salts increase the oxidation resistance from the molecular level, but the mechanism of adding inorganic solid electrolytes to enhance the electrochemical window is not clear. For the positive electrode of S with lower voltage, the solid electrolyte is thought to solve the shuttle effect of polysulfides that always exist in the liquid electrolyte. In polymer lithium-sulfur battery, the charge–discharge curve is similar to that of liquid electrolyte [139]. Because of working at high temperature, the property of polymer at high temperature is like that of liquid electrolyte, which can’t well inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfides (Fig. 14d). Fang et al. [140] also found that in the discharge process of lithium-sulfur battery assembled by PEO, S has a multi-step solid–liquid-solid reaction path. But in PVDF, it is a direct solid–solid one-step reaction mechanism (Fig. 14e).
