However, the ionic conductivity is improved due to the addition of inorganic solid electrolyte in the composite electrolyte, so that the lithium-sulfur battery does not need to be carried out at high temperature. Secondly, inorganic fillers have an impedance effect on polysulfides. Cui’s group filled PEO with Al3+/Nb5+ co-doped cubic LLZO nanoparticles synthesized by sol–gel method [141]. The sulfur composite cathode based on LLZO@C (Fig. 14f) can have a capacity of more than 900 mA h g−1 at human body temperature 37 °C, and has a high capacity of 1210 and 1556 mA h g−1 at 50 °C and 70 °C, respectively. The excellent cycle performance and Coulomb efficiency show that the composite electrolyte can effectively inhibit the increase of interfacial impedance and capacity attenuation caused by the shuttle of polysulfides to the negative electrode. In summary, the good performance of the composite electrolyte can be achieved by the Lewis acid-base interaction and reasonable structural design, no matter in the high voltage cathode or S cathode. But in the interface problem, we still have a lot of unknown places waiting for us to explore. 5 Summary, perspectives, and challenges 5.1 Summary of this review paper From the perspectives of design strategies and interface engineering, this paper presents a review of the development and main issues of lithium batteries based on CSEs (as outlined in Fig. 15 ). Achieving high safety, high specific energy, and long cycle life of batteries is feasible through the utilization of a solid electrolyte. Composite solid electrolytes made of inorganic fillers and polymer matrix serve as effective means of comprehensively enhancing the lithium-ion conductivity, mechanical strength, puncture resistance, and interface stability of solid electrolytes. This paper also introduces the mechanism by which the composite solid electrolyte enhances the lithium-ion conductivity, electrochemical stability, and inhibits the formation of lithium dendrites. While a long way remains needed for the practicality and industrialization of composite electrolytes, they hold promise for the future of lithium batteries. 5.2 Perspectives and challenges Although this review summarizes many recent advancements and an increasing quantity of research on CSEs, it is clear that further investigation is necessary as the current research is in its early stages. Despite progress made, there remain key problems pertaining to CSEs, such as inferior electrochemical performance, safety concerns, and limited understanding of mechanisms for ionic transport. Therefore, further exploration of these perspectives and challenges is necessary to advance the field. More detailed information regarding these challenges can be found in the following sections. (1) Electrochemical performance: To enhance the electrochemical performance of polymer solid electrolytes, several strategies can be applied. Firstly, the electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte must be broadened. This can be achieved by regulating the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of the polymer electrolytes through molecular structure design or the introduction of functional groups based on the frontier molecular orbital theory. Increasing the LUMO energy level while reducing the HOMO energy level can broaden the stability window, aligning it with both the high-voltage positive electrode and the metal lithium negative electrode. Secondly, a new type of lithium salt can be developed to promote the formation of a stable interfacial phase layer between the positive and negative interfaces. By decomposing the lithium anion preferentially to the polymer, the interface properties of solid-state batteries can be regulated. This can be achieved by designing the lithium anion structure or using multi-lithium salt. Additionally, single-ion conductive polymers can be synthesized by immobilizing anions on polymer segments, which increases the lithium-ion transference number of polymer electrolytes and helps prevent the formation of lithium dendrites. Thirdly, the electrochemical stability and ionic conductivity of the composite electrolyte greatly depend on the inorganic solid electrolyte used. Thus, incorporating inorganic fillers into the polymer electrolyte can improve the properties of the composite electrolytes. The interaction between inorganic fillers and polymers must be effectively utilized to optimize the composite electrolyte. Fourthly, several methods, such as casting, ball milling, electrospinning, and in-situ polymerization, can be used to prepare composite electrolytes. However, the dispersion and interfacial compatibility of inorganic fillers in the composite electrolyte must be considered for each method used. Lastly, it is necessary to explore large-scale manufacturing processes for composite electrolytes, as it is just as important for manufacturing liquid batteries. Reformation of existing processes can be done to produce composite electrolytes on a large scale. (2) Safety performance: Liquid electrolytes present safety challenges such as flammability and leakage, which can be resolved through the use of solid electrolytes. However, the safety concerns of composite solid electrolytes must also be fully examined. One major issue is the safety concern arising from battery short-circuiting. Dendrite formation, which leads to a short circuit, is easy to occur in liquid electrolytes. In composite solid electrolytes, however, inorganic solid electrolyte fillers possessing high mechanical strength can deter the propagation of lithium dendrites. Although the present composite solid electrolytes typically operate under small currents, studies of performance and safety under high-current working conditions lag behind. It is imperative to explore the mode of dendrite propagation in composite solid electrolytes under high-current conditions. A short-circuited battery will release a large amount of heat, enough to cause commercial separators to curl up at 80 °C. A common issue with liquid electrolytes is poor thermal stability since the organic electrolyte and separator can act as a fuel for combustion. The composite solid electrolyte contains organic polymer electrolytes that could also fuel combustion; however, the inclusion of the inorganic phase improves the composite solid electrolyte's decomposition temperature. The composite solid electrolyte can still retain its structural integrity at 160 °C. Nevertheless, the limited use of composite solid electrolytes in button batteries only partially showcases its performance. For large-sized soft-pack batteries, the application of composite solid electrolytes becomes more complicated. Industrial assessments, such as acupuncture experiments, need to be carried out to verify the safety of composite solid electrolytes in assembling large-capacity soft-pack batteries. (3) Mechanism: The composite electrolyte used in lithium-ion batteries is not yet fully understood. While some aspects of the lithium conduction mechanism have been studied, the basic understanding of ion transport through the interface is still limited. The changes in the ion transport interface during charging and discharging are yet to be fully understood. The formation mechanism of the percolation network is also not fully understood. In conclusion, a universal lithium-ion transport mechanism has not yet been clearly proposed. To further explore the mechanism of lithium conduction in the composite electrolyte system, a combination of experiments and calculations will be conducted. The formation and propagation of lithium dendrites in composite electrolytes is another area that requires further exploration. Lithium symmetrical batteries and full batteries are typically tested at low currents where the nucleation and growth of metal negative electrode are mainly controlled by intrinsic electrochemical reaction. Composite electrolytes can conduct lithium ions uniformly at low current to inhibit the nucleation of lithium dendrites. However, the electrodeposition behavior of lithium metal is mainly controlled by the diffusion process at a relatively high current density. Thus, the uniformity of ion distribution at the reaction interface and the transference rate of ions in the composite electrolytes to the reaction interface will be the two main factors to control the morphology of metal deposition under high rate. However, there are few studies on the inhibition of lithium dendrite by composite electrolytes at high current. At high current, a series of problems need to be studied, such as the aggravation of the side reaction of the composite electrolyte, the lack of lithium-ion transport capacity, and the possibility of the SEI formed by the interfacial reaction being destroyed. The lack of understanding of many of these mechanisms is attributed primarily to difficulties in characterization. Although there are many techniques available in the material field for characterization, there are few methods that can accurately characterize the interface components. Most components of the interface film are highly unstable to air and electron beam, making them difficult to study. In addition, the interfacial film of solid-state batteries typically has a small size, on the nanometer scale, and composite electrolytes are difficult to disassemble from electrodes after use. High temperature or electron beam radiation can lead to changes in ion and atom distribution, resulting in changes in the composition of the interface. Therefore, it is crucial to use advanced and reliable characterization methods to investigate these issues in the future. coredata.dc:description: The rapid development of new energy vehicles and 5G communication technologies has led to higher demands for the safety, energy density, and cycle performance of lithium-ion batteries as power sources. However, the currently used liquid carbonate compounds in commercial lithium-ion battery electrolytes pose potential safety hazards such as leakage, swelling, corrosion, and flammability. Solid electrolytes can be used to mitigate these risks and create a safer lithium battery. Furthermore, high-energy density can be achieved by using solid electrolytes along with high-voltage cathode and metal lithium anode. Two types of solid electrolytes are generally used: inorganic solid electrolytes and polymer solid electrolytes. Inorganic solid electrolytes have high ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability window, and mechanical strength, but suffer from large solid/solid contact resistance between the electrode and electrolyte. Polymer solid electrolytes have good flexibility, processability, and contact interface properties, but low room temperature ionic conductivity, necessitating operation at elevated temperatures. Composite solid electrolytes (CSEs) are a promising alternative because they offer light weight and flexibility, like polymers, as well as the strength and stability of inorganic electrolytes. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent advances in CSEs to help researchers optimize CSE composition and interactions for practical applications. It covers the development history of solid-state electrolytes, CSE properties with respect to nanofillers, morphology, and polymer types, and also discusses the lithium-ion transport mechanism of the composite electrolyte, and the methods of engineering interfaces with the positive and negative electrodes. Overall, the paper aims to provide an outlook on the potential applications of CSEs in solid-state lithium batteries, and to inspire further research aimed at the development of more systematic optimization strategies for CSEs.
